multimedia.caption: Health Minutes: Cancer and Diet

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Gina Kolata of The Times discusses the hypothetical and elusive correlation between diet and cancer prevention.

multimedia.credit: Gina Kolata of The Times discusses the hypothetical and elusive correlation between diet and cancer prevention.

headline.main: Which of These Foods Will Stop Cancer? (Not So Fast)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leslie Michelson does not have prostate cancer, but as chief executive officer of the Prostate Cancer Foundation he knows all too well how bad the disease is. So Mr. Michelson, 54, changed his diet. He used to avoid cruciferous vegetables, like cauliflower and brussels sprouts, hating their taste. Now he has them three or four times a week. He rarely ate fish, but now has it three times a week. He eats tomato sauce at least twice a week.
docs.snippet: When it comes to cancer, eating well can't hurt. But for now, scientists say, the benefits remain hypothetical and elusive.
